Ryan Stevenson
Oct 24, 2016

The Cream Trip

Laura’s alarm intrusively beeped and abruptly started the day. ‘Time to get up,’ instructed Laura in a chirpy tone that filled me with instant agitation, as she seamlessly transitioned from slumber to being instantly awake and ready for the day in the blink of an eye.

Today Laura had booked yet another day of fun in The Bay. The only problem with that was early start to the day. I’m not quite sure how she does it but Laura’s brain just instantly pings into awake mode in the morning, whilst mine takes several hours to start to function; during which time, I only seem capable of grunts and having a bemused look on my face. I have trained my body through several years of muscle memory though, to retrieve all the essential components that make up cereal and find my way to the sofa.

‘Come on,’ buoyed Laura, ‘We’ve go to leave soon.’ I looked at her. ‘Why are you confused?’ she asked.

I grunted a noise in her general direction before continuing to shovel cereal into my mouth.

Finally, she shepherded me out of the house and we marched down the hill and presented ourselves at Fullers for our boat ride around The Bay.

The lady politely scanned our tickets, ‘I’m sorry, this trip doesn’t leave for another hour.’

Laura looked apologetically at me.

I was secretly delighted. This was the first of many good things that would happen throughout the course of the day.

‘Let’s go get a coffee,’ I declared whilst raising my eyebrows at Laura in a patronising way.

‘Sorry for getting you up an hour early,’ said Laura.

I replied, ‘That’s quite alright,’ in a way that insinuated that it actually it wasn’t quite alright.

‘At least you’ve got a coffee,’ Laura continued.

‘I’d rather be in bed,’ I said whilst actually being quite glad that we were up and about.

Finally came the time when we had to wander back to the wharf. We’d booked onto The Cream Trip, which involves an entire day exploring various islands and The Bay and topping it off by driving the boat through the infamous Hole in the Rock.

Almost as quickly as we were out on the water, we received a radio message from another boat that there was a pod of dolphins out in the middle of the open water of the bay.

Sure enough, we soon came across a pod of common dolphins.

‘I’m afraid, we can’t swim with these dolphins,’ said the captain. It didn’t matter though, we were having a great time just watching them play off the bow of the boat, now that I’d woken up a bit.

I managed to take only 300 photos to capture one good one.

The dolphins were great fun and were clearly having a brilliant time playing off the front of the boat but after 15 minutes we continued our journey over to Nine Pin and the hoards of nesting gannets.

From there we continued south around the bays and towards Black Rocks. Black Rocks were formed a long time ago, I’m not sure how long ago…let’s just say definitely over 10 years ago, to be safe. They were formed from volcanic debris that hit the water and cooled rather rapidly to make some interesting rock formations.

Here we dropped off one of the crew members to cut some mussels off the rocks, whilst we circled around and enjoyed the scenery.

It was then that I managed to snap this rather outstanding picture!

I showed Laura and she rolled her eyes, ‘Stop taking pictures of the front of the brochure. You can see the crinkles in the paper.’

‘Fair enough,’ I said as we continued to wander around the deck.

After picking the member of crew up, who’d been picking the mussels, we headed west over towards Motuarohia Island (otherwise known as Roberton Island).

After a quick tour amongst the islands, we spotted some bottle-nose dolphins just off the side of the boat.

‘We can’t swim with them for another 5 minutes because there are strict limits to make sure that they’re not hounded by tourists all the time,’ said the captain.

We were sure that they’d all just swim away but if anything, they came closer to the boat.

Time passed but then the captain said, ‘I’m afraid, I think that they have a young dolphin in the pod, so we can’t swim today folks.’

We were gutted that we couldn’t go swimming with them but also a tiny bit relieved that we didn’t have to get into the cold water.

Then the captain changed his mind again, ‘On a closer inspection, it’s not a baby dolphin, so we can jump in.’

There was a mad rush get swim shorts on, wetsuits, masks, snorkels and fins and with dolphins in the water, I was busy pushing tourists out the way left, right and centre.

Thankfully, my Dad had rather kindly purchased me a Go-Pro last Christmas, so I jumped in with it. The water took my breath away but it didn’t matter, there were dolphins in the water.

I couldn’t see much, so I dived down to try and see if I could spot any dolphins.

They were busy flipping out of the water but they were still a little distance away from us.

Then they started coming closer.

I dived down but I couldn’t see anything at first…

Then they were everywhere, swimming in amongst us and playing around us. They were having a great time and it was utterly incredible.

I could have easily reached out and stroked one. It was sensational to be interacting and playing with these beautiful creatures in the wild.

Back on the boat, we were left shell-shocked by just how phenomenal the experience was. Our friend, Rachel, who happens to work on the boats stated that was easily the best experience she’d ever had in the water with dolphins.

Next we were off to Urupukapuka Island but I was too busy flicking through the videos on my GoPro to really enjoy the views.

We ended up having a great hike around the island with Rachel and our friend Chris, whilst mainly talking about swimming with dolphins.

‘Was it worth getting up for?’ asked Laura.

I had to concede, ‘Yes it was but don’t do it again.’

Well played Laura. Top show.

Not even going through The Hole in the Rock could spoil our day.
